channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. B-52 Flight Prompts Indignant Reaction in China
item.description: A flight by American B-52 bombers in an air defense zone declared by China over a set of disputed islands is being viewed as a test of Chinese resolve.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A map outlining the air defense zone China declared Saturday in the East China Sea.

item.title: Guangzhou Journal: With Glut of Lonely Men, China Has an Approved Outlet for Unrequited Lust
item.description: The Guangzhou National Sex Culture Festival is where hedonism meets capitalism in China, and its mostly male visitors reflect the country’s gender imbalance.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: The one-child rule is a factor in China’s gender imbalance.

item.title: Firm Charged With Defying Sanctions Settles With U.S.
item.description: In one of the biggest settlements for corporate misbehavior overseas, a Swiss oil services company agreed to pay over $250 million to resolve charges that included defiance of sanctions against Iran.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Pays Homage to Confucius, a Figure Back in Favor
item.description: The Chinese president suggests that Confucius’ thinking deserves attention, but only through the prism of Communist Party views.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Statues of the ancient sage at the Temple of Confucius in Beijing. Confucius has been both attacked and honored by the Communist Party as a symbol of traditional values.

item.title: U.S. Sends Two B-52 Bombers Into Air Zone Claimed by China
item.description: Two long-range American bombers have conducted what Pentagon officials described as a routine training mission through international air space recently claimed by China.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: The Cancer Divide: In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted
item.description: As a push ensues in Israel for a screening program to test Jewish women for cancer-causing gene mutations, many face hard choices about how much they want to know.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: This 28-year-old woman discovered a large lump in her left breast last year. Years earlier, her mother's half-sister, who lives in Canada, tested positive for a genetic mutation that increases cancer risk and then warned her Israeli relatives.

item.title: Egyptian Riot Police Attack Peaceful Protests in Cairo
item.description: Officers beat, sexually harassed and detained some of Egypt’s most prominent human rights activists in a crackdown that could broaden opposition to the military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Plainclothes officers detained a protester in downtown Cairo on Tuesday, two days after the adoption of a law that regulates demonstrations.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Suicide Bombers Kill 16 Soldiers and Policemen
item.description: Four suicide bombers struck northern Baghdad, targeting an army base and a police station, killing 10 soldiers and six policemen, police and medical officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: The Lede: Egypt’s Jon Stewart on Comedy and Politics
item.description: Bassem Youssef talks about the future of his show, the turbulent political situation in Egypt, and what it is like to be a comedian in a country plagued by violence, division and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israeli Forces Kill 3 Suspected Militants
item.description: The military said the militants were linked to a violent Islamist movement known as the Salafi Jihadis, which draws inspiration from Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: U.S. Asks for Help in Finding Missing American
item.description: In an apparent effort to test Iranian good will after a landmark nuclear deal, the United States asked Iran for help in finding an American who has been missing there for more than six years.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Romania: Leaders of Dutch Museum Theft Sentenced
item.description: Two leaders of a gang who stole paintings by Matisse, Monet and Picasso from a Dutch museum were given sentences of six years and eight months.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Cuba, Lacking Bank, Closes U.S. Consular Services
item.description: The Cuban government said it was shutting down nearly all of its consular services in the United States “until further notice” because it was unable to find a bank willing to handle its business.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: Karzai’s Bet: U.S. Is Bluffing in Warning on Security Pact
item.description: Even many of President Hamid Karzai’s friends have criticized his refusal to conclude a security agreement with the United States.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai on Sunday at the gathering of Afghan leaders whose advice on a security agreement he has rejected.

item.title: Pope Sets Down Goals for an Inclusive Church, Reaching Out ‘on the Streets’
item.description: Francis said women must play an increasingly important role in the church, but that letting women be priests was “not a question open to discussion.”
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis called for "a new phase of evangelization, one marked by enthusiasm and vitality."

item.title: At Least 30 Haitians Die After Boat Capsizes
item.description: The fatal accident is the latest in a series of shipwrecks involving Haitian migrants, who pay smugglers to ferry them to the United States in often unseaworthy vessels.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: The overcrowded boat off the Bahamas, which was found late Monday. More than 100 people on the vessel were rescued, but at least 30 perished.

item.title: Judge Says Statements by Bin Laden’s Son-in-Law Can Be Used in Terrorism Case
item.description: A judge ruled that despite the contention of lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, he had been read his rights before an F.B.I. interrogation and his statements had been voluntary.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ukraine in Turmoil After Leaders Reject Major E.U. Deal
item.description: Tens of thousands of protesters have demanded that the country shake off its post-Soviet identity and move into the orbit of a more prosperous Europe.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: The Lede: Prominent Egyptian Activists Detained for Protesting Under New Law
item.description: Video posted online showed police officers aiming a water cannon directly at protesters, including several prominent activists, who were chanting against Egyptian military rule outside the upper house of Parliament in Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: W.H.O. Estimate of Swine Flu Deaths in 2009 Rises Sharply
item.description: The World Health Organization funded the research, which found that related consequences of the flu pushed the toll to about 400,000.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: India Ink: A New University Offers Liberal Arts as Higher Education Alternative
item.description: The founders of Ashoka University aspire to establish an alternative to what they say is an educational paradigm that overly emphasizes technical capabilities.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: An artist's impression of Ashoka University, currently under construction in Kundli, Haryana.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Group Skeptical of Talks
item.description: The planned international conference on ending Syria’s civil war encountered its first obstacles, a day after it was announced in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Scots Propose Independence With Pounds And Passports
item.description: The proposal, 670 pages long, is part of an effort by Scottish authorities to answer many questions about the implications of a referendum next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Health Group Retracts Report on H.I.V. in Greece
item.description: The World Health Organization blamed an editing error for a widely reported claim that many Greeks infect themselves to get benefit payments.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM

item.title: Brazil Is Entranced by a Tale of Love, Taxes and Bribery
item.description: How did an $82,000-a-year tax inspector amass a fortune said to be about $8 million? Prosecutors offer an explanation.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
